revision.text:
A '''polytopic group''' is a cyclic group whose group operation is the multiplication of a unital algebra. The elements of the group are points in the space of the given algebra, and their convex hull is a specific '''polytope''' in that space.
==Examples== * In <math>\Bbb{X}_2</math> (also know as the complex numbers or <math>\Bbb{C}</math>, there's an infinite number of two-dimensional polytopic groups. These are the classical "roots of unity" whose convex hulls are polygons.
* In <math>\Bbb{X}_3</math>, there are polytopic groups of polygons as well polytopic groups of antiprisms (polyhedra).

A '''polytopic group''' is a [[wikipedia:Cyclic group|cyclic group]] whose group operation is the multiplication of a unital algebra. The elements of the group are points in the space of the given algebra, and their convex hull is a specific '''polytope''' in that space.
As such, a polytopic group can be characterized by it convex hull. For example, a polytopic group of a tetrahedron has four elements (corresponding to the four vertices of the tetrahedron) with a three-dimensional span (since a tetrahedron is a three-dimensional polytope).

* In <math>\Bbb{X}_3</math>, there are polytopic groups of regular polygons as well as polytopic groups of antiprisms (polyhedra).

Given a real unital algebra <math>A</math> with a bilinear multiplication <math>*</math>, a '''polytopic group''' is any [[wikipedia:Cyclic group|cyclic group]] <math>\left(P\subset{A},*\right)</math>. The convex hull of <math>P</math> is a specific '''polytope'''. This concept generalizes the roots of unity in the complex plane, which form polygons in the space.
A polytopic group can be characterized by its convex hull. For example, a polytopic group of a tetrahedron necessarily has four elements (corresponding to the four vertices of the tetrahedron) with a three-dimensional span (since a tetrahedron is a three-dimensional polytope).
==Examples== * A [[wikipedia:Group ring|group algebra]] of a cyclic group trivially has a polytopic group of a simplex as its basis.
* An [[orthoplexic group]] is a polytopic group of an <math>n</math>-orthoplex.
* In [[wikipedia:Complex number|<math>\Bbb{X}_2</math>]] (also known as the complex numbers or <math>\Bbb{C}</math>), there's an infinite number of two-dimensional polytopic groups. These are the classical "roots of unity" whose convex hulls are polygons.
* In <math>\Bbb{X}_3</math>, there are polytopic groups of regular polygons as well as polytopic groups of antiprisms (polyhedra).

* An [[orthoplexic group]] is a polytopic group of an <math>n</math>-orthoplex.
* In [[wikipedia:Complex number|<math>\Bbb{X}_2</math>]] (also known as the complex numbers or <math>\Bbb{C}</math>), there's an infinite number of two-dimensional polytopic groups. These are the classical [[wikipedia:Root of unity|roots of unity]] whose convex hulls are polygons.
* In <math>\Bbb{X}_3</math>, there are polytopic groups of regular polygons as well as polytopic groups of antiprisms (polyhedra).

A polytopic group can be characterized by its convex hull. For example, a polytopic group of a tetrahedron necessarily has four elements (corresponding to the four vertices of the tetrahedron) with a three-dimensional span (since a tetrahedron is a three-dimensional polytope).

Given a real unital algebra <math>A</math>, a '''polytopic group''' is any [[wikipedia:Cyclic group|cyclic group]] <math>\left(P\subset{A},*\right)</math>, where <math>*</math> is the bilinear multiplication in <math>A</math>. The convex hull of <math>P</math> is a specific '''polytope'''. This concept generalizes the roots of unity in the complex plane, which form polygons in the space.
A polytopic group can be characterized by its convex hull. For example, a polytopic group of a tetrahedron necessarily has four elements (corresponding to the four vertices of the tetrahedron) with a three-dimensional span (since a tetrahedron is a three-dimensional polytope).
Multiple polytopic groups of the same order (not necessarily the same number of dimensions) may exist in the same algebra.
==Examples== * A [[wikipedia:Group ring|group algebra]] of a cyclic group over the reals trivially has a polytopic group of a simplex as its basis.
* An [[orthoplexic group|<math>n</math>-orthoplexic group]] is a polytopic group of an <math>n</math>-orthoplex.
* In [[complex number|<math>\Bbb{X}_2</math>]] (also known as the [[wikipedia:Complex number|complex numbers]] or <math>\Bbb{C}</math>), there's an infinite number of two-dimensional polytopic groups. These are the classical [[wikipedia:Root of unity|roots of unity]] whose convex hulls are regular polygons.
* In [[Triplex number|<math>\Bbb{X}_3</math>]], there are polytopic groups of regular polygons as well as those of antiprisms. Both combined form an [[wikipedia:algebraic group|algebraic group]] whose convex hull is a cylinder.
* In [[tessarines|<math>\Bbb{X}_4</math>]], for any <math>x\in\mathbb{N}</math>, there are <math>x</math> polytopic groups of order <math>x</math>.

For a given natural number <math>n</math>, a '''polytopic''' algebra is an <math>n</math>-dimensional unital algebra that contains <math>n</math>-dimensional [[Polytopic group|polytopic groups]].
This article will focus on a certain family of <math>n</math>-dimensional polytopic algebras denoted as <math>\Bbb{X}_{n}</math>.
==Orthonormal basis== <math>\Bbb{X}_{n}</math> contains an orthonormal basis made up of the positive elements of an [[Orthoplexic group|<math>n</math>-orthoplexic group]].

For a given natural number <math>n</math>, a '''polytopic''' algebra is an <math>n</math>-dimensional unital algebra that contains <math>n</math>-dimensional [[Polytopic group|polytopic groups]].
This article will focus on a certain family of <math>n</math>-dimensional polytopic algebras denoted as <math>\Bbb{X}_{n}</math>.
==Orthonormal basis== <math>\Bbb{X}_{n}</math> contains an orthonormal basis made up of the positive elements of an [[Orthoplexic group|<math>n</math>-orthoplexic group]].
Thus, the basis is half of the orthoplexic group. For odd values of <math>n</math>, the basis itself is a polytopic group of an <math>(n-1)</math>-simplex. This means that for an odd number <math>m</math>, <math>\Bbb{X}_{m}=\Bbb{R}[C_{m}]</math> is the group algebra of the cyclic group of order <math>m</math> over the reals.

For a given natural number <math>n</math>, a '''polytopic''' algebra is an <math>n</math>-dimensional unital algebra that contains <math>n</math>-dimensional [[Polytopic group|polytopic groups]].
This article will focus on a certain family of <math>n</math>-dimensional polytopic algebras denoted as <math>\Bbb{X}_{n}</math>.
==Orthonormal basis== <math>\Bbb{X}_{n}</math> contains an orthonormal basis made up of the positive elements of an [[Orthoplexic group|<math>n</math>-orthoplexic group]].
Thus, the basis is half of the orthoplexic group. For odd values of <math>n</math>, the basis itself is a polytopic group of an <math>(n-1)</math>-simplex. This means that for an odd number <math>m</math>, <math>\Bbb{X}_{m}\cong\Bbb{R}[C_{m}]</math> is the group algebra of the cyclic group of order <math>m</math> over the reals.

For a given natural number <math>n</math>, a '''polytopic''' algebra is an <math>n</math>-dimensional unital algebra that contains <math>n</math>-dimensional [[Polytopic group|polytopic groups]].
This article will focus on a certain family of <math>n</math>-dimensional polytopic algebras denoted as <math>\Bbb{X}_{n}</math>.
==Orthonormal basis== <math>\Bbb{X}_{n}</math> contains an orthonormal basis made up of the positive elements of an [[Orthoplexic group|<math>n</math>-orthoplexic group]]. We can denote them as <math>\{1,x_n,x_n^2,\dots,x_n^{n-1}\}</math>. When an integer <math>f</math> is a factor of <math>n</math>, then <math>x_n^f=x_{n/f}</math>
By definition, the basis is half of the orthoplexic group. For odd values of <math>n</math>, the basis itself is a polytopic group of an <math>(n-1)</math>-simplex. This means that for an odd number <math>m</math>, <math>\Bbb{X}_{m}\cong\Bbb{R}[C_{m}]</math> is the group algebra of the cyclic group of order <math>m</math> over the reals.
For even values of <math>n</math>, on the other hand, the basis is not a group.

For a given natural number <math>n</math>, a '''polytopic''' algebra is an <math>n</math>-dimensional unital algebra that contains <math>n</math>-dimensional [[Polytopic group|polytopic groups]].
This article will focus on a certain family of <math>n</math>-dimensional polytopic algebras denoted as <math>\Bbb{X}_{n}</math>.
==Orthonormal basis== <math>\Bbb{X}_{n}</math> contains an orthonormal basis made up of the positive elements of an [[Orthoplexic group|<math>n</math>-orthoplexic group]]. We can denote them as <math>\{1,x_n,x_n^2,\dots,x_n^{n-1}\}</math>.

:<math>\mathbb{X}_2\cong\mathbb{C}</math>

An element <math>v\in\Bbb{X}_{n}</math> with coordinates <math>(c_1,c_2,c_3\dots,c_n)</math> in this basis has the following Cartesian form:

It is a group of order <math>2n</math>, containing both <math>n</math> orthonormal elements as well as their additive inverses. Since polytopic groups are subsets of real algebras, the meaning of "additive inverse" and "<math>-1</math>" is clear in the context, despite the fact that the group operation is not addition.

revision.text:
Given a natural number <math>n</math>, the '''<math>\bf{n}</math>-orthoplexic group''' is a [[polytopic group]] of an [[wikipedia:orthoplex|<math>n</math>-orthoplex]]. It is a group of order <math>2n</math>, with elements equidistant to a central point in the vector space. Half of the elements are orthogonal to each other with respect to their center, while the other half contain the opposites of the first half with respect to the center.
When the center of the group is the algebra's <math>0</math> or origin, the orthoplexic group can be presented as <math>\langle{g|g^n=-1}\rangle</math>, and each element in the group is an additive inverse of another element. Since polytopic groups are subsets of real algebras, the meaning of "additive inverse" and "<math>-1</math>" is clear in the context, despite the fact that the group operation is not addition.
==Example==
A <math>4</math>-orthoplexic group <math>\langle{g}\rangle</math> centered at the origin has 8 elements: <math>\{1,g,g^2,g^3,-1,-g,-(g^2),-g^3\}</math>. The set <math>\{1,g,g^2,g^3\}</math> is an orthonormal basis of <math>\Bbb{X}_4</math>.

==Example==
A <math>4</math>-orthoplexic group <math>\langle{g}\rangle</math> centered at the origin has 8 elements: <math>\{1,g,g^2,g^3,-1,-g,-(g^2),-g^3\}</math>. The set <math>\{1,g,g^2,g^3\}</math> is an orthonormal basis of <math>\Bbb{X}_4</math>.

Orthoplexic groups can have differing properties and conventions depending on whether their dimension is odd or even.
===Generators=== For a <math>2m</math>-orthoplexic group <math>\langle{x_{2m}}\rangle</math>, which has even dimensions <math>2m</math> and order <math>4m</math>, the generator's additive inverse <math>-x_{2m}</math> is also a generator of the same orthoplexic group.

This is not the case for orthoplexic groups with odd dimension. For a <math>(2m+1)</math>-orthoplexic group, while a generator has order <math>4m+2</math>, its additive inverse has order <math>2m+1</math>. So they don't generate the same group.

This is motivated by the <math>1</math>-orthoplexic group <math>\{1,-1\}</math>, since <math>-1</math> has a higher order than <math>1</math>. ==Central Orthoplexic Group== When the center of the group is the origin, the orthoplexic group can be presented as <math>\langle{g\mid{g^n=-1, g^a\perp{g^b}\mbox{ if }g^a\neq{-(g^b)}\forall{a,b}\in\mathbb{Z}}}\rangle</math> and is called the '''central orthoplexic group''' <math>X_n</math>. Here, the opposite of each element is their additive inverse.
This article will focus on central orthoplexic groups.
==The <math>\chi_n</math> notation==
There is a particular convention when denoting elements of a central orthoplexic group, for example the <math>10</math> elements of <math>X_5</math>, to distinguish it from other cyclic groups of the same order.
In any central orthoplexic group <math>X_n</math>, a choice is made to designate one of the elements as <math>\chi_n</math>. If <math>n</math> is even, <math>\chi_n</math> is one of the generators of the <math>n</math>-orthoplexic group. And if <math>n</math> is odd, it is the additive inverse of such a generator (meaning the generator is <math>-\chi_n</math>). In either case, the group's <math>2n</math> elements can be rewritten in terms of <math>\chi_n</math> as the following set:
:<math>\{1,\chi_n,\chi_n^2,\dots,\chi_n^{n-1},-1,-\chi_n,-(\chi_n^2),\dots,-\chi_n^{n-1}\}</math>
===Simplification and the basis subset=== As a convention, a basis element <math>\chi_{ab}^{cb}</math> is considered equivalent to <math>\chi_{a}^{c}</math> for any <math>a,b,c\in\mathbb{Z}</math> if <math>a</math> and <math>ab</math> have the same parity. Otherwise, if <math>a</math> is odd but <math>ab</math> is even, then <math>\chi_{ab}^{cb}=(-\chi_{a})^{c}</math>. So for example, <math>\chi_6^3=\chi_2</math> and <math>\chi_6^4=(-\chi_3)^2=\chi_3^2</math>, but <math>\chi_6^2=-\chi_3</math>. This means that all elements of <math>X_n</math> exist in <math>X_{nm}</math> at least by convention, not just <math>1</math> and <math>-1</math>.
Once all elements have been simplified, the set of all the positive simplest-form elements of <math>X_n</math> becomes the '''orthoplexic basis''' used by the [[polytopic algebra]] <math>\Bbb{X}_n</math>.
==Parity-Based Differences==
Orthoplexic groups can have differing properties and conventions depending on whether their dimension is odd or even.
===Generators=== For a <math>2m</math>-orthoplexic group <math>\langle{\chi_{2m}}\rangle</math>, which has even dimensions <math>2m</math> and order <math>4m</math>, the generator's additive inverse <math>-\chi_{2m}</math> is also a generator of the same orthoplexic group.
:<math>\langle{\chi_{2m}}\rangle=\langle{-\chi_{2m}}\rangle</math>
This is not the case for orthoplexic groups with odd dimension. For a <math>(2m+1)</math>-orthoplexic group, while a generator has order <math>4m+2</math>, its additive inverse has order <math>2m+1</math>. So they don't generate the same group.
For such odd dimensions, when additive inverses have different orders, we will mark the one with lower order positive, and the one with the higher order negative. This is motivated by the <math>1</math>-orthoplexic group <math>\{1,-1\}</math>, since <math>-1</math> has a higher order than <math>1</math>. Another motivation for this will be explained in the section on matrix representations.
By this convention, a <math>(2m+1)</math>-orthoplexic group <math>\langle{-\chi_{2m+1}}\rangle</math> has a '''negative''' generator. By contrast, the additive inverse <math>+\chi_{2m+1}</math> is instead a generator of a [[polytopic group]] of a <math>2m</math>-simplex.

For the even-dimensional case representing <math>\chi_{2m}</math>, that matrix has a determinant of <math>1</math>. For the the odd-dimensional case representing <math>-\chi_{2m+1}</math>, its determinant is <math>-1</math>. This negative determinant is another motivation for the negative generator convention for (2m+1)-orthoplexic groups.
Aside from the additive inverse of the matrix above, the positive element <math>\chi_{2m+1}</math> can also be represented by a circulant <math>(2m+1)\times(2m+1)</math> permutation matrix:

Since <math>2m+1</math> is odd, the determinant is <math>1</math>.

Given <math>n\in\mathbb{N}</math>, the '''<math>\bf{n}</math>-orthoplexic group''' is a [[polytopic group]] of an [[wikipedia:orthoplex|<math>n</math>-orthoplex]]. It is a group of order <math>2n</math>, with elements equidistant to a central point in the vector space. Each element <math>k</math> of the group has an opposite element <math>k'</math> with respect to the center, and <math>k</math> is orthogonal to all other elements in the group with respect to the center except <math>k'</math>.
==Central Orthoplexic Group== When the center of the group is the origin, the orthoplexic group can be presented as <math>\langle{g\mid{g^n=-1, g^a\perp{g^b}\forall{a,b}\in\mathbb{Z}\mbox{ if }g^a\neq{-(g^b)}}}\rangle</math> and is called the '''central orthoplexic group''' <math>X_n</math>. Here, the opposite of each element is their additive inverse.
This article will focus on central orthoplexic groups.
==The <math>\chi_n</math> notation==
There is a particular convention when denoting elements of a central orthoplexic group, for example the <math>10</math> elements of <math>X_5</math>, to distinguish it from other cyclic groups of the same order.
In any central orthoplexic group <math>X_n</math>, a choice is made to designate one of the elements as <math>\chi_n</math>. If <math>n</math> is even, <math>\chi_n</math> is one of the generators of the <math>n</math>-orthoplexic group. And if <math>n</math> is odd, it is the additive inverse of such a generator (meaning the generator is <math>-\chi_n</math>). In either case, the group's <math>2n</math> elements can be rewritten in terms of <math>\chi_n</math> as the following set:
:<math>\{1,\chi_n,\chi_n^2,\dots,\chi_n^{n-1},-1,-\chi_n,-(\chi_n^2),\dots,-\chi_n^{n-1}\}</math>
===Simplification=== As a convention, an element <math>\chi_{ab}^{cb}</math> is equated to <math>\chi_{a}^{c}</math> for any <math>a,b,c\in\mathbb{Z}</math> if <math>a</math> and <math>ab</math> have the same parity. Otherwise, if <math>a</math> is odd but <math>ab</math> is even, then <math>\chi_{ab}^{cb}=(-\chi_{a})^{c}</math>. Here are some examples in <math>X_6</math>:
:<math>\chi_6^2=-\chi_3</math>
:<math>\chi_6^3=\chi_2</math>
:<math>\chi_6^4=(-\chi_3)^2=\chi_3^2</math>
:<math>\chi_6^6=(\chi_1)=-1</math>
:<math>\chi_6^8=(-\chi_3)^4=\chi_3^4=\chi_3</math>
===Orthoplexic basis===
The set of all the positive simplest-form elements of <math>X_n</math> is called the '''orthoplexic basis''' and it is the conventional basis of the [[polytopic algebra]] <math>\Bbb{X}_n</math>.
For example, in the case of <math>X_6</math>, the orthoplexic basis of the polytopic algebra <math>\Bbb{X}_6</math> is the set <math>\{1,\chi_2,\chi_3,\chi_3^2,\chi_6,\chi_6^5\}</math>. Other possible bases for a particular <math>\Bbb{X}_n</math> might be more desirable in certain situations (as in the case of the [[tessarines]], where the traditional basis is relatively simpler), but this convention unifies all polytopic algebras by constructing their basis on top of each other.
==Parity-Based Differences==
Orthoplexic groups can have differing properties and conventions depending on whether their dimension is odd or even.
===Generators=== For a <math>2m</math>-orthoplexic group <math>\langle{\chi_{2m}}\rangle</math>, which has even dimensions <math>2m</math> and order <math>4m</math>, the generator's additive inverse <math>-\chi_{2m}</math> is also a generator of the same orthoplexic group.

This is not the case for orthoplexic groups with odd dimension. For a <math>(2m+1)</math>-orthoplexic group, while a generator has order <math>4m+2</math>, its additive inverse has order <math>2m+1</math>. So they don't generate the same group.
For such odd dimensions, when additive inverses have different orders, we will mark the one with lower order positive, and the one with the higher order negative. This is motivated by the <math>1</math>-orthoplexic group <math>\{1,-1\}</math>, since <math>-1</math> has a higher order than <math>1</math>. Aside from the additive inverse of the matrix above, the positive element <math>\chi_{2m+1}</math> can also be represented by a circulant <math>(2m+1)\times(2m+1)</math> permutation matrix:

Since <math>2m+1</math> is odd, the determinant is <math>1</math>.

If the set of components are <math>\{c_1,c_2,\dots,c_n\}</math>, then the <math>n</math>-rational number can be written as <math>c_1\blacktriangleright{c_2}\blacktriangleright{\dots}\blacktriangleright{c_n}</math>.

'''Multirational numbers''' are multi-component structures that represent mappings from a subset of homogeneous coordinates to a subspace of a [[polytopic algebra]]. An '''<math>\bf{n}</math>-rational number''' is a multirational number with <math>n</math> components. These components come from a set of <math>n</math> homogeneous coordinates <math>(c_1:c_2:\dots:c_n)</math> and are combined into an <math>n</math>-rational number, which can be written as <math>c_1\blacktriangleright{c_2}\blacktriangleright{\dots}\blacktriangleright{c_n}</math>. This then evaluates to a specific element in <math>\mathbb{X}_{n-1}</math>
==Examples== * The <math>2</math>-rational numbers are of the form <math>c_1\blacktriangleright{c_2}</math> and are just another name for fractions, i.e. <math>\frac{c_1}{c_2}</math>. The case where both components are integers results in a field classically known as the field of rational numbers <math>\mathbb{Q}\in\mathbb{X}_1</math>.
* The <math>3</math>-rational numbers, also called the [[Trirational number|trirational numbers]], differ from fractions in that only the first component (the "numerator") of a trirational number can be negative. Trirational numbers with components from <math>\mathbb{X}_1\cong\mathbb{R}</math> evaluate to an element of the complex numbers <math>\mathbb{X}_2\cong\mathbb{C}</math>
==Construction== Given a set of <math>n</math> homogeneous coordinates <math>(c_1:c_2:c_3:\dots:c_n)</math>, one can combine them using the following exponential product:
:<math>c_1^1*c_2^s*c_3^{s^2}*\dots*c_n^{s^{n-1}}</math>
Where <math>\{1,s,s^2,\dots,s^{n-1}\}</math> is a polytopic group of an <math>(n-1)</math>-simplex in <math>\mathbb{X}_{n-1}</math>. This product can be rewritten as the <math>n</math>-rational number <math>c_1\blacktriangleright{c_2}\blacktriangleright{\dots}\blacktriangleright{c_n}</math>. For real components, this will of course evaluate to an element in <math>\mathbb{X}_{n-1}</math>.

'''Multirational numbers''' are multi-component structures that represent mappings from homogeneous coordinates to elements of a [[polytopic algebra]]. An '''<math>\bf{n}</math>-rational number''' is a multirational number with <math>n</math> components. These components come from a set of <math>n</math> homogeneous coordinates <math>(c_1:c_2:\dots:c_n)</math> and are combined into an <math>n</math>-rational number, which can be written as <math>c_1\blacktriangleright{c_2}\blacktriangleright{\dots}\blacktriangleright{c_n}</math>. This then evaluates to a specific element in <math>\mathbb{X}_{n-1}</math>
==Terminology== For an <math>n</math>-rational number <math>r\blacktriangleright{d_1}\blacktriangleright{d_2}\blacktriangleright{\dots}\blacktriangleright{d_{n-1}}</math>, the first component <math>r</math> is called the '''numerator'''. The other components <math>\{d_1,d_2,\dots,d_{n-1}\}</math> after the numerator are called as the '''denominators''' of the multirational number.
==Examples== * The <math>2</math>-rational numbers can be written as <math>c_1\blacktriangleright{c_2}</math>, but they are more commonly known as fractions, i.e. <math>\frac{c_1}{c_2}</math>. The case where both components are integers results in the field <math>\mathbb{Q}\in\mathbb{X}_1</math>, commonly called the field of "rational numbers" (without a prefix).
* The <math>3</math>-rational numbers, also called the [[Trirational number|trirational numbers]], differ from fractions in that only the numerator of a trirational number <math>a\blacktriangleright{b}\blacktriangleright{c}</math> can be less than zero. Trirational numbers with components from <math>\mathbb{X}_1\cong\mathbb{R}</math> evaluate to an element of the complex numbers <math>\mathbb{X}_2\cong\mathbb{C}</math>.
==Construction== Given a set of <math>n</math> homogeneous coordinates <math>(c_1:c_2:c_3:\dots:c_n)</math>, one can combine them using the following exponential product:
:<math>c_1^1*c_2^s*c_3^{s^2}*\dots*c_n^{s^{n-1}}</math>
Where <math>\{1,s,s^2,\dots,s^{n-1}\}</math> is an [[simplexic group|<math>(n-1)</math>-simplexic group]] in <math>\mathbb{X}_{n-1}</math>. This product can be rewritten as the <math>n</math>-rational number <math>c_1\blacktriangleright{c_2}\blacktriangleright{\dots}\blacktriangleright{c_n}</math>. For real components, this will of course evaluate to an element in <math>\mathbb{X}_{n-1}</math>.
===Invalid components=== As an exception to the above construction, no multirational number can have '''zero''' as one of its denominators. This is because <math>c_1^1*c_2^s*c_3^{s^2}*\dots*c_n^{s^{n-1}}=c_1*e^{s\ln(c_2)}*e^{s^2\ln(c_3)}*\dots*e^{s^{n-1\ln(c_n)}}</math> and <math>\ln(0)</math> is undefined.
==Operations== ===Multiplication=== Multirational multiplication is component-wise.

Given <math>n\in\mathbb{N}</math>, the '''<math>\bf{n}</math>-simplexic group''' is a [[polytopic group]] of an [[wikipedia:simplex|<math>n</math>-simplex]]. It is a group of order <math>n+1</math>, with elements equidistant to a central point in the vector space as well as equidistant to each other.
==Central Simplexic Group== When the center of the group is the origin, any element <math>x\neq{1}</math> in the simplexic group has the real component <math>\Re(x)=-\frac{1}{n}</math>.
===Multirationals=== Given a central simplexic group <math>\{1,s,s^2,\dots,s^{n-1}\}</math>, the exponential product <math>c_1^1*c_2^s*c_3^{s^2}*\dots*c_n^{s^{n-1}}</math> is a [[multirational number]].

{{About|tessarines as a polytopic algebra|the classical treatments of tessarines and their history|Wikipedia:Tessarines}}
The '''tessarines''' are a four-dimensional [[polytopic algebra]] also called <math>\mathbb{X}_4</math>.

{{About|tessarines as a polytopic algebra|the classical treatments of tessarines and their history|Wikipedia:Tessarines}}
The '''tessarines''' are a four-dimensional [[polytopic algebra]], denoted as <math>\mathbb{X}_4</math> in the polytopic algebra notation. It is isomorphic to <math>\mathbb{C}^2</math> and its multiplication is commutative.
==Orthonormal basis== As a four-dimensional polytopic algebra, the tessarines include a [[orthoplexic group|central orthoplexic group]] with the subset <math>\{1,\chi_4,\chi_4^2, chi_4^3\}</math> that can be used as an orthonormal basis.
On the other hand, the tessarines are classically known to have a different basis commonly denoted as <math>\{1,i,j,k\}</math>, where <math>i^2=k^2=-1,ij=k</math>, implying <math>j^2=1</math>.

The '''tessarines''' are a four-dimensional [[polytopic algebra]], denoted as <math>\mathbb{X}_4</math>. It is isomorphic to <math>\mathbb{C}\times\mathbb{C}</math>.
==Orthonormal basis== As a four-dimensional polytopic algebra, the tessarines include a [[orthoplexic group|central orthoplexic group]] with the subset <math>\{1,\chi_4,\chi_4^2,\chi_4^3\}</math> that can be used as an orthonormal basis.

==Orthonormal basis== As a four-dimensional polytopic algebra, the tessarines include a [[orthoplexic group|central orthoplexic group]] with the subset <math>\{1,\chi_4,\chi_2,\chi_4^3\}</math> that can be used as an orthonormal basis.
On the other hand, the tessarines are classically known for a different basis commonly denoted as <math>\{1,i,j,k\}</math>, where <math>i^2=k^2=-1,ij=k</math>, implying <math>j^2=1,kj=i</math>.
We can map one basis to the other in several ways that generate algebras isomorphic to each other. The one that will be used in this article is the following:
:<math>i=\chi_2</math>
:<math>j=\frac{\chi_4-\chi_4^3}{\sqrt{2}}</math>
:<math>k=\frac{\chi_4+\chi_4^3}{\sqrt{2}}</math>
==Central <math>4</math>-simplexic groups== The tesserines have two [[simplexic group#Central_simplexic_groups|central <math>4</math>-simplexic groups]], both centered at the origin. Here they are in terms of the classical tessarine basis:
:<math>\left\langle{-\frac{1}{4}+\frac{\sqrt{5+2\sqrt{5}}}{4}i+\frac{\sqrt{5}}{4}j+ \frac{2\sqrt{5(5+2\sqrt{5})}-\sqrt{\frac{(5+2\sqrt{5})^3}{5}}} {4}k}\right\rangle</math>
:<math>\left\langle{-\frac{1}{4}+\frac{\sqrt{5-2\sqrt{5}}}{4}i+\frac{\sqrt{5}}{4}j+ \frac{2\sqrt{5(5-2\sqrt{5})}-\sqrt{\frac{(5-2\sqrt{5})^3}{5}}} {4}k}\right\rangle</math>
This means that there are two different variants of [[multirationals|<math>5</math>-rational numbers]] in the tessarines.
==Central <math>4</math>-cubic group== It is known that all the permutations of Cartesian coordinates <math>(\pm{1},0,0,0)</math> combined with all the permutations of <math>(\pm{0.5},\pm{0.5},\pm{0.5},\pm{0.5})</math> with an odd number of <math>-0.5</math> are the vertices of a [[wikipedia:tesseract|tesseract]] or <math>4</math>-cube. These relatively simple coordinates do not form a group in the orthoplexic basis, but they fortunately do form a [[cubic group|<math>4</math>-cubic group]] in the classical basis. This group has the following (polytopic) sub groups
* <math>\langle{i}\rangle</math> (square) * <math>\langle{j}\rangle</math> (line segment) * <math>\langle{k}\rangle</math> (square) * <math>\langle{0.5 - 0.5i + 0.5j + 0.5k}\rangle</math> (tetrahedron) * <math>\langle{0.5 + 0.5i - 0.5j + 0.5k}\rangle</math> (tetrahedron) * <math>\langle{-0.5 + 0.5i - 0.5j - 0.5k}\rangle</math> (tetrahedron) * <math>\langle{-0.5 - 0.5i + 0.5j - 0.5k}\rangle</math> (tetrahedron)

revision.text:
The '''triplex numbers''' are a three-dimensional [[polytopic algebra]], denoted as <math>\mathbb{X}_3</math>. It is isomorphic to <math>\mathbb{R}\times\mathbb{C}</math> and is also the group algebra of the cyclic group <math>C_3</math>.
==Orthonormal basis== As a polytopic algebra, the tessarines include a [[orthoplexic group#Central_polytopic_groups|central orthoplexic group]] with a subset that can be used as an orthonormal basis. In this case, it has a <math>2</math>-simplexic subgroup for such a purpose: <math>\{1,\chi_3,\chi_3^2\}</math>
In other literature, the triplex basis elements are sometimes denoted <math>\{1,i,j\}</math> or <math>\{1,j,k\}</math>. This article will use the orthoplexic group element naming convention in order to avoid ambiguity.
==Central <math>3</math>-simplexic groups== The triplex numbers have the following [[simplexic group#Central_simplexic_groups|central <math>3</math>-simplexic group]]:
:<math>\left\langle{-\frac{1}{3}+\frac{(\sqrt{3}-1)}{3}j-\frac{(\sqrt{3}+1)}{3}k}\right\rangle</math>
This can be used to create [[multirationals|<math>4</math>-rational numbers]] in triplex space.
==Central cubic group== Since the <math>3</math>-simplex is also the demicube, the elements of the central <math>3</math>-simplexic group and their negatives will have a cube as the convex hull. They also form a group.

This can be used to create [[multirationals|<math>4</math>-rational numbers]] in triplex space.

In this case, it has a <math>2</math>-simplexic subgroup for such a purpose: <math>\{1,\chi_3,\chi_3^2\}</math>.
In other literature, the triplex basis elements are sometimes denoted <math>\{1,i,j\}</math> or <math>\{1,j,k\}</math>. This article will use the orthoplexic group element naming convention in order to avoid ambiguity.

:<math>\left\langle{-\frac{1}{3}+\frac{(\sqrt{3}-1)}{3}\chi_3-\frac{(\sqrt{3}+1)}{3}\chi_3^2}\right\rangle</math>
This can be used to create [[multirationals|<math>4</math>-rational numbers]] in triplex space.
==Central cubic group== Since the <math>3</math>-simplex is also the demicube, the elements of the central <math>3</math>-simplexic group and their negatives will have a cube as the convex hull. All eight elements also form a group, although this is not a polytopic group because it is not cyclic.

{{About|complex numbers as a polytopic algebra|the classical treatment of complex numbers|Wikipedia:Complex number}}
The '''complex numbers''' are a two-dimensional [[polytopic algebra]], denoted as <math>\mathbb{X}_2</math> or, more commonly, <math>\mathbb{C}</math>. They are also called '''binarions'''.
==Orthonormal basis== As a two-dimensional polytopic algebra, the complex numbers include a [[orthoplexic group|central orthoplexic group]] with the subset <math>\{1,\chi_2\}</math> that is an orthonormal basis. <math>\chi_2</math> is traditionally denoted as <math>i</math> by mathematicians and as <math>j</math> by engineers.
==Central <math>2</math>-simplexic groups== The complex numbers have a [[simplexic group#Central_simplexic_groups|central <math>2</math>-simplexic group]] generated by <math>\left\langle{-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{sqrt{3}}{4}i}\right\rangle</math>
:<math>\left\langle{-\frac{1}{4}+\frac{\sqrt{5-2\sqrt{5}}}{4}i+\frac{\sqrt{5}}{4}j+ \frac{2\sqrt{5(5-2\sqrt{5})}-\sqrt{\frac{(5-2\sqrt{5})^3}{5}}} {4}k}\right\rangle</math>
This means that there are two different variants of [[multirationals|<math>5</math>-rational numbers]] in the tessarines.
==Central <math>4</math>-cubic group== It is known that all the permutations of Cartesian coordinates <math>(\pm{1},0,0,0)</math> combined with all the permutations of <math>(\pm{0.5},\pm{0.5},\pm{0.5},\pm{0.5})</math> with an odd number of <math>-0.5</math> are the vertices of a [[wikipedia:tesseract|tesseract]] or <math>4</math>-cube. These relatively simple coordinates do not form a group in the orthoplexic basis, but they fortunately do form a [[cubic group|<math>4</math>-cubic group]] in the classical basis. This group has the following (polytopic) sub groups
* <math>\langle{i}\rangle</math> (square) * <math>\langle{j}\rangle</math> (line segment) * <math>\langle{k}\rangle</math> (square) * <math>\langle{0.5 - 0.5i + 0.5j + 0.5k}\rangle</math> (tetrahedron) * <math>\langle{0.5 + 0.5i - 0.5j + 0.5k}\rangle</math> (tetrahedron) * <math>\langle{-0.5 + 0.5i - 0.5j - 0.5k}\rangle</math> (tetrahedron) * <math>\langle{-0.5 - 0.5i + 0.5j - 0.5k}\rangle</math> (tetrahedron)

{{About|complex numbers as a polytopic algebra|the classical treatment of complex numbers|Wikipedia:Complex number}}
The '''complex numbers''' are a two-dimensional [[polytopic algebra]], denoted as <math>\mathbb{X}_2</math> or, more commonly, <math>\mathbb{C}</math>. They are also called '''binarions'''.
==Orthonormal basis== As a two-dimensional polytopic algebra, the complex numbers include a [[orthoplexic group|central orthoplexic group]] with the subset <math>\{1,\chi_2\}</math> that is an orthonormal basis. <math>\chi_2</math> is traditionally denoted as <math>i</math> by mathematicians and as <math>j</math> by engineers.
==Central <math>2</math>-simplexic group== The complex numbers have a [[simplexic group#Central_simplexic_groups|central <math>2</math>-simplexic group]] generated by <math>\left\langle{-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{sqrt{3}}{2}\chi_2}\right\rangle</math>.
This means that [[trirational numbers]] exist in the complex plane.
==Central <math>2</math>-cubic group== A <math>2</math>-orthoplex is the same as a <math>2</math>-cube in that they're both just a square. Similarly, the central <math>2</math>-cubic group is the same as the <math>2</math>-orthoplexic group in the complex numbers.

{{About|complex numbers as a polytopic algebra|the classical treatment of complex numbers|Wikipedia:Complex number}}
The '''complex numbers''' are a two-dimensional [[polytopic algebra]], denoted as <math>\mathbb{X}_2</math> or, more commonly, <math>\mathbb{C}</math>. They are also called '''binarions'''.
==Orthonormal basis== As a two-dimensional polytopic algebra, the complex numbers include a [[orthoplexic group|central orthoplexic group]] with the subset <math>\{1,\chi_2\}</math> that is an orthonormal basis. <math>\chi_2</math> is traditionally denoted as <math>i</math> by mathematicians and as <math>j</math> by engineers.
==Central <math>2</math>-simplexic group== The complex numbers have a [[simplexic group#Central_simplexic_groups|central <math>2</math>-simplexic group]] generated by <math>\left\langle{-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt3}{2}\chi_2}\right\rangle</math>.
This means that [[trirational numbers]] exist in the complex plane.
==Central <math>2</math>-cubic group== A <math>2</math>-orthoplex is the same as a <math>2</math>-cube in that they're both just a square. Similarly, the central <math>2</math>-cubic group is the same as the <math>2</math>-orthoplexic group in the complex numbers.

{{About|complex numbers as a polytopic algebra|the classical treatment of complex numbers|Wikipedia:Complex number}}
The '''complex numbers''' are a two-dimensional [[polytopic algebra]], denoted as <math>\mathbb{X}_2</math> or, more commonly, <math>\mathbb{C}</math>. They are also called '''binarions'''.
==Cartesian form== As a two-dimensional polytopic algebra, the complex numbers have a Cartesian form based on the orthonormal basis <math>\{1,\chi_2\}</math>, which is a subset of the [[orthoplexic group|central orthoplexic group]] <math>X_2</math>. A complex number <math>v</math> can be written in the form <math>v=z+y\chi_2</math> where <math>(z,y)</math> are the real Cartesian coordinates of <math>v</math> in the basis.
<math>\chi_2</math> is traditionally denoted as <math>i</math> by mathematicians and as <math>j</math> by engineers.
==Polar form== The complex numbers' polar form uses an element of the central <math>2</math>-cubic group, which is the same as the <math>2</math>-orthoplexic group in that both are the same polytopic group of the square <math>\{1,\chi_2,-1,-\chi_2\}</math>. Specifically, for a complex number <math>v</math> with the polar coordinates <math>(r,\theta)</math> the complex polar form uses <math>\chi_2</math>:
:<math>v=e^{\theta\chi_2}</math>
==Homogeneous form== The complex numbers have a [[simplexic group#Central_simplexic_groups|central <math>2</math>-simplexic group]] generated by <math>\left\langle{-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt3}{2}\chi_2}\right\rangle</math>. This allows for the creation of the homogeneous form of complex numbers called the [[trirational numbers]].

{{About|complex numbers as a polytopic algebra|the classical treatment of complex numbers|Wikipedia:Complex number}}
The '''complex numbers''' are a two-dimensional [[polytopic algebra]], denoted as <math>\mathbb{X}_2</math> or, more commonly, <math>\mathbb{C}</math>. They are also called '''binarions'''.
==Cartesian form== As a two-dimensional polytopic algebra, the complex numbers have a Cartesian form based on the orthonormal basis <math>\{1,\chi_2\}</math>, which is a subset of the [[orthoplexic group|central orthoplexic group]] <math>X_2</math>. A complex number <math>v</math> can be written in the form <math>v=z+y\chi_2</math> where <math>(z,y)</math> are the real Cartesian coordinates of <math>v</math> in the basis.
<math>\chi_2</math> is traditionally denoted as <math>i</math> by mathematicians and as <math>j</math> by engineers.
==Polar form== The complex numbers' polar form uses an element of the central <math>2</math>-cubic group, which is the same as the <math>2</math>-orthoplexic group in that both are the same polytopic group of the square <math>\{1,\chi_2,-1,-\chi_2\}</math>. Specifically, for a complex number <math>v</math> with the polar coordinates <math>(r,\theta)</math> the complex polar form uses <math>\chi_2</math>:
:<math>v=e^{\theta\chi_2}</math>
==Homogeneous form== The complex numbers have a [[simplexic group#Central_simplexic_groups|central <math>2</math>-simplexic group]] generated by <math>\left\langle{-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt3}{2}\chi_2}\right\rangle</math>. This allows for the creation of the homogeneous form of complex numbers called the [[trirational numbers]]:
:<math>z\blacktriangleright{y}\blacktriangleright{x}</math>

{{About|complex numbers as a polytopic algebra|the classical treatment of complex numbers|Wikipedia:Complex number}}
The '''complex numbers''' are a two-dimensional [[polytopic algebra]], denoted as <math>\mathbb{X}_2</math> or, more commonly, <math>\mathbb{C}</math>. They are also called '''binarions'''.
==Cartesian form== As a two-dimensional polytopic algebra, the complex numbers have a Cartesian form based on the orthonormal basis <math>\{1,\chi_2\}</math>, which is a subset of the [[orthoplexic group|central orthoplexic group]] <math>X_2</math>. A complex number <math>v</math> can be written in the form <math>v=z+y\chi_2</math> where <math>(z,y)</math> are the real Cartesian coordinates of <math>v</math> in the basis.
<math>\chi_2</math> is traditionally denoted as <math>i</math> by mathematicians and as <math>j</math> by engineers.
==Polar form== The complex numbers' polar form uses an element of the central <math>2</math>-cubic group, which is the same as the <math>2</math>-orthoplexic group in that both are the same polytopic group of the square <math>\{1,\chi_2,-1,-\chi_2\}</math>. Specifically, for a complex number <math>v</math> with the polar coordinates <math>(r,\theta)</math> the complex polar form uses <math>\chi_2</math>:
:<math>v=e^{\theta\chi_2}</math>
==Homogeneous form== The complex numbers have a [[simplexic group#Central_simplexic_groups|central <math>2</math>-simplexic group]] generated by <math>\left\langle{-\frac{1}{2}+\frac{\sqrt3}{2}\chi_2}\right\rangle</math>. This allows for the creation of the homogeneous form of complex numbers called the [[trirational numbers]] such that three homogeneous coordinates <math>(z:y:x)</math> can be expressed as a complex number <math>v</math> when the following trirational is evaluated:
:<math>v=z\blacktriangleright{y}\blacktriangleright{x}</math>

{{About|groups whose elements are the vertices of an <math>n</math>-cube|the symmetry group of a cube|Wikipedia:Octahedral symmetry}}
An '''<math>\bf{n}</math>-cubic group''' is any abelian group of elements in an algebra where the elements form the vertices of an <math>n</math>-cube.
==Central <math>n</math>-cubic group== In any [[polytopic algebra]] <math>\mathbb{X}_n</math>, there is always an <math>n</math>-cubic group centered at the origin. This is the '''central <math>\bf{n}</math>-cubic group''' denoted as <math>\bf\Gamma_n</math> and is isomorphic to the following abelian groups:
:<math>\Gamma_1\cong{C_2}</math>
:<math>\Gamma_2\cong{C_4}</math>
:<math>\Gamma_n\cong\begin{cases} C_2\times{C_4^{m}}, & \text{if $n=2m+1$ (odd)} \\ C_4^{m}, & \text{if $n=2m$ (even)} \end{cases},\forall{m\in\mathbb{N}}</math>
==Examples== * For <math>n\leq{2}</math>, the central <math>n</math>-cubic group coincides with the [[orthoplexic group#Central_orthoplexic_group|central orthoplexic group]]. * <math>\Gamma_3</math> contains all four elements of the [[simplexic group#central_simplexic_group|central 3-simplexic group]] as well as their additive inverses, adding to a total of eight elements. <math>\Gamma_3</math> also contains a (non-central) 2-cubic group <math>\left\langle{\frac{1}{3}-\frac{\sqrt{3}-1}{3}\chi_3+\frac{(\sqrt{3}+1)}{3}\chi_3^2}\right\rangle</math>.

{{About|groups whose elements are the vertices of an <math>n</math>-cube|the symmetry group of a cube|Wikipedia:Octahedral symmetry}}
An '''<math>\bf{n}</math>-cubic group''' is any abelian group of elements in an algebra where the elements form the vertices of an <math>n</math>-cube.
==Central <math>n</math>-cubic group== In any [[polytopic algebra]] <math>\mathbb{X}_n</math>, there is always an <math>n</math>-cubic group centered at the origin. This is the '''central <math>\bf{n}</math>-cubic group''' denoted as <math>\bf\Gamma_n</math> and is isomorphic to the following abelian groups:
:<math>\Gamma_1\cong{C_2}\text{ (cyclic)}</math>
:<math>\Gamma_2\cong{C_4}\text{ (cyclic)}</math>
:<math>\Gamma_n\cong\begin{cases} C_2\times{C_4^{m}}, & \text{if $n=2m+1$ (odd)} \\ C_4^{m}, & \text{if $n=2m$ (even)} \end{cases},\forall{m\in\mathbb{N}}</math>
==Examples== * For <math>n\leq{2}</math>, the central <math>n</math>-cubic group coincides with the [[orthoplexic group#Central_orthoplexic_group|central orthoplexic group]]. * <math>\Gamma_3</math> contains all four elements of the [[simplexic group#central_simplexic_group|central 3-simplexic group]] as well as their additive inverses, adding to a total of eight elements. <math>\Gamma_3</math> also contains a (non-central) 2-cubic group <math>\left\langle{\frac{1}{3}-\frac{\sqrt{3}-1}{3}\chi_3+\frac{(\sqrt{3}+1)}{3}\chi_3^2}\right\rangle</math>.
